column1: #Text=Author of “ While the Billy Boils ” , “ On the Track and Over the Sliprails ” , “ When the World was Wide , and other verses ” , “ Verses , Popular and Humorous ” , “ Children of the Bush ” , “ When I was King , and other verses ” , etc.
#Text=Some carry their swags in the Great North-West Where the bravest battle and die , And a few have gone to their last long rest , And a few have said “ Good-bye ! ”
#Text=The coast grows dim , and it may be long Ere the Gums again I see ; So I put my soul in a farewell song To the chaps who barracked for me .
#Text=Their days are hard at the best of times , And their dreams are dreams of care --
#Text=God bless them all for their big soft hearts , And the brave , brave grins they wear ! God keep me straight as a man can go , And true as a man may be !
#Text=For the sake of the hearts that were always so , Of the men who had faith in me !
#Text=And a ship-side word I would say , you chaps
#Text=The world will call it a boast , perhaps -- But I ’ll win , if a man can win !
#Text=And not for gold nor the world ’s applause --
#Text=Though ways to the end they be -- I ’ll win , if a man might win , because Of the men who believed in me .
#Text=I. A Lonely Track . II . ‘ Past Carin ’ ’ .
#Text=Told by One of the Other Drovers .
#Text=There are many times in this world when a healthy boy is happy .
#Text=When he is put into knickerbockers , for instance , and ‘ comes a man to-day , ’ as my little Jim used to say .
#Text=When they ’re cooking something at home that he likes .

#Text=When the ‘ sandy-blight ’ or measles breaks out amongst the children , or the teacher or his wife falls dangerously ill -- or dies , it does n’t matter which -- ‘and there ai n’t no school . ’ When a boy is naked and in his natural state for a warm climate like Australia , with three or four of his schoolmates , under the shade of the creek-oaks in the bend where there ’s a good clear pool with a sandy bottom .
#Text=When his father buys him a gun , and he starts out after kangaroos or ‘ possums .
#Text=When he gets a horse , saddle , and bridle , of his own .
#Text=When he has his arm in splints or a stitch in his head -- he ’s proud then , the proudest boy in the district .
#Text=I was n’t a healthy-minded , average boy :
#Text=I reckon I was born for a poet by mistake , and grew up to be a Bushman , and did n’t know what was the matter with me -- or the world -- but that ’s got nothing to do with it .
#Text=There are times when a man is happy .
#Text=When he finds out that the girl loves him . When he ’s just married .
#Text=When he ’s a lawful father for the first time , and everything is going on all right : some men make fools of themselves then -- I know I did .
#Text=I ’m happy to-night because I ’m out of debt and can see clear ahead , and because I have n’t been easy for a long time .
#Text=But I think that the happiest time in a man ’s life is when he ’s courting a girl and finds out for sure that she loves him and has n’t a thought for any one else .
#Text=Make the most of your courting days , you young chaps , and keep them clean , for they ’re about the only days when there ’s a chance of poetry and beauty coming into this life .
#Text=Make the best of them and you ’ll never regret it the longest day you live .

#Text=They ’re the days that the wife will look back to , anyway , in the brightest of times as well as in the blackest , and there should n’t be anything in those days that might hurt her when she looks back .
#Text=Make the most of your courting days , you young chaps , for they will never come again .

#Text=A married man knows all about it -- after a while : he sees the woman world through the eyes of his wife ; he knows what an extra moment ’s pressure of the hand means , and , if he has had a hard life , and is inclined to be cynical , the knowledge does him no good .
#Text=It leads him into awful messes sometimes , for a married man , if he ’s inclined that way , has three times the chance with a woman that a single man has -- because the married man knows .

#Text=He is privileged ; he can guess pretty closely what a woman means when she says something else ; he knows just how far he can go ; he can go farther in five minutes towards coming to the point with a woman than an innocent young man dares go in three weeks .
#Text=Above all , the married man is more decided with women ; he takes them and things for granted .
#Text=In short he is -- well , he is a married man .
#Text=And , when he knows all this , how much better or happier is he for it ?
#Text=Mark Twain says that he lost all the beauty of the river when he saw it with a pilot ’s eye , -- and there you have it .
